Award.AwardTitle: 2016 Frontiers of Engineering Symposia (Japan-America: Irvine, California, June 2016; U.S.: Houston, Texas, September 2016; and European Union-U.S.: October 2016)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Frontiers of Engineering (FOE) Symposia, organized by the National Academy of Engineering (NAE), provide emerging engineering leaders from academia, industry, and government laboratories the opportunity to share research insights to facilitate an interdisciplinary transfer of knowledge and research methodologies. The nature of emerging technologies and how they fit together to create products and processes that drive economic growth in an increasingly competitive environment have heightened the need for engineers to understand each other's disciplines and enhance the value in that interaction, particularly among those developing and using these new technologies. The symposia serve as a catalyst to spur engineering innovation and foster collaborative networks of researchers within the United States and between engineers from the United States and partnering countries.

This award provides partial support for three FOE Symposia, to be held in 2016, organized by the NAE for early career researchers: the 2016 Japan-America FOE Symposium (JAFOE) to be held on June 16-18, 2016, in Irvine, California; the 2016 U.S. FOE Symposium (USFOE) to be held on September 19-21, 2016, in Houston, Texas; and the 2016 European Union-U.S. FOE Symposium (EU-US FOE) to be held on October 17-19, 2016, in Helsinki, Finland. Each FOE symposium will focus on four topical areas. The four topics for the 2016 USFOE Symposium are scalable algorithms and software for high-fidelity graphics, technologies for eradicating cancer, water desalination and purification, and extreme engineering. The four topics for the 2016 JAFOE Symposium are advanced 3D printing; nanotechnology in energy generation, storage and efficiency; big data; and urban mobility efficiency. Finally, the four topics for the 2016 EU-US FOE Symposium are carbon capture, utilization, and storage; information and computer technologies for personal health; integrated photonics manufacturing; and intelligent transportation systems. About 100 outstanding young engineers for the US FOE Symposium and 30 from each country for the bilateral symposia will participate. Each two and one-half day symposium will include four formal sessions, technical tours, break-out sessions, and opportunities for developing collaborative research partnerships. Sessions will consist of presentations on cutting-edge research, innovations, and emerging research opportunities in engineering fields relevant to the symposium. Papers from the USFOE Symposium will be published in a volume available on the National Academies Press website at http://www.nap.edu.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Frontiers of Engineering (FOE) program brings together a select group of engineers (ages 30-45) from industry, academia, and government labs for 2.5-day meetings to discuss pioneering technical work and leading-edge research in various engineering fields and industry sectors. The goal is to facilitate an interdisciplinary exchange of knowledge and methodology that could lead to collaborative networks of engineers. NSF provided partial funding for three FOE symposia in 2016: US Frontiers of Engineering (US FOE) held September 19-21 in Irvine, California; Japan-America Frontiers of Engineering (JAFOE) held June 16-18 in Irvine, California; and EU-US Frontiers of Engineering (EU-US FOE) held October 17-19 in Espoo, Finland. Over 220 engineers attended the symposia where selected topics such as high-performance computer graphics and vision, technologies for understanding and treating cancer, nanotechnology in energy storage and conversion, additive manufacturing, integrated photonics, and smart systems for personalized health care were covered. Symposium materials can be found at www.naefrontiers.org.

Outcomes from evaluation forms:

US FRONTIERS OF ENGINEERING

Rated good or excellent:
Meeting format 100%
Choice of topics 93%
Quality of presentations 98%
Level of engineering covered  98%
Your opportunity to participate 98%

Comments:

"It is such a wonderful symposium and  a great eye-opening opportunity to see what people are doing in other fields. The topics cover a broad spectrum of engineering including CS, ME, ChemE, BME, MSE; are multidisciplinary in nature; and the quality of the presentations is world-class."

"Loved the range of topics. Enough depth per topic to sink your teeth into a subject but broad enough to get excited about the diversity."

"What a great mix of expertise across the participants! Great job on the selection process, and 1/3 of the attendees were female! Amazing!!"

"I have already started conversations with two people in very different fields I am definitely going to try to collaborate with."

"Tying the things I learned at the symposium directly to my work at the practical level will be a little challenging because I have a very narrow field of work. But overall, I believe I am a better engineer for having gone, and there will definitely be intangible benefits to the way I approach my job."

"This was a fantastic networking opportunity and just a very broadening, inspiring experience."

JAPAN-AMERICA FRONTIERS OF ENGINEERING

Rated good or excellent:
Meeting format 97%
Choice of topics 86%
Quality of presentations 84%
Level of engineering covered  80%
Your opportunity to participate 89%

Comments:

"I look forward to using this information for better understanding of Japan's approach to science and engineering research."

"The poster session was fantastic. The small group work and the assigned tables at dinner forced conversations that would have otherwise not necessarily happened. While these were initially uncomfortable for everyone, I very much appreciated the effort to do that."

"The intensive program and friendly atmosphere gave me a lot of inspiration about other fields as well as mine."

"It was a great experience to interact with talented engineers from academia and industry. The meeting presentations, poster sessions, and informal discussions were intellectually stimulating and have given me a few good ideas. I also learned a lot about new areas that I would not have been exposed to otherwise."

EU-US FRONTIERS OF ENGINEERING

Rated good or excellent:
Meeting format 100%
Choice of topics 97%
Quality of presentations 100%
Level of engineering covered  100%
Your opportunity to participate 97%

Comments:

"I enjoyed this meeting very much and was honored to be part of it. The talks were great and inspired great discussions. I'm looking forward to the relationships that I have made here."

"This symposium was truly great in broadening my perspective on the applications of other fields to my own work."

"I identified some new, collaborative opportunities that I am now pursuing. A number of new, interdisciplinary ideas and approaches were also identified."

"As I have told people before, the NAE FOE symposium is possibly the most intellectually stimulating event I have had the pleasure of participating in. It not only covers topics close to my own area of research but surely fulfills its vision of allowing the mind to be stretched by topics and discussions disparate from one's own. I am grateful for the opportunity to participate!"

"I really appreciated learning about the interdisciplinary applications of methods based on machine learning, big data analysis, etc."


GRAINGER GRANTS AWARDED

Two grants of $30,000 from The Grainger Foundation were awarded to 2016 US FOE attendees who developed collaborative research projects:

Julian Rimoli (Georgia Tech) and Marco Pavone (Stanford University) for, "Tensegrity Damping Strategies for Controlled Hopping on Small Solar System Bodies."

Amin Karbasi (Yale University) and Amit Surana (United Technologies Research Center) for, "A Unified Approach for Saliency Detection in Heterogenous Temporal Data."


LONG-TERM IMPACT SURVEY

The grant provided funding to conduct a survey of all US-based FOE alumni to determine the impact of participation in the program. Results were sent to NSF in December 2016.
